name: Seated Leg Press
setupSteps: Sit on the machine with your back flat against the padded support
Place your feet on the footplate shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly outward
Adjust the seat position so your knees are at about 90 degrees when starting
Grip the handles on the sides for stability
Release the safety locks on either side once you're in position
howToSteps: Press through your heels to extend your legs, pushing the platform away
Stop just before your knees fully lock out (keep a slight bend)
Slowly lower the weight by bending your knees
Control the descent until your knees return to about 90 degrees
Repeat for desired reps, then re-engage safety locks before exiting
commonMistakes: Locking knees completely at the top of the movement
Letting knees cave inward instead of tracking over toes
Rounding the lower back by going too deep
Using momentum or bouncing at the bottom
Placing feet too high or too low on the platform
safetyTips: Always engage the safety locks before getting on or off the machine
Never lock your knees at full extension
Keep your back pressed firmly against the pad throughout
If you feel sharp pain in your knees or back, stop immediately
Start with lighter weight to master the form
beginnerTips: Focus on controlled movement rather than heavy weight
Breathe out as you press, breathe in as you lower
Keep your core engaged to protect your lower back
Your knees should track in line with your toes throughout the movement
Start with 3 sets of 10-12 reps with moderate weight

name: Lat Pulldown
setupSteps: Adjust the knee pad so it sits comfortably on your thighs to prevent lifting
Sit down and reach up to grab the wide bar with an overhand grip
Hands should be wider than shoulder-width apart
Plant your feet flat on the floor
Sit upright with a slight lean back (about 10-15 degrees)
howToSteps: Pull the bar down toward your upper chest while keeping your torso still
Focus on driving your elbows down and back
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the bottom of the movement
Slowly return the bar to the starting position with control
Keep tension in your lats throughout the entire range of motion
commonMistakes: Pulling the bar behind the neck (can strain shoulders)
Using momentum by swinging the torso excessively
Shrugging shoulders up toward ears
Not pulling down far enough to engage the lats fully
Letting the weight pull your arms up too fast
safetyTips: Always pull to the front of your chest, not behind your neck
Don't use weight so heavy that you need to jerk or swing
Keep your shoulders down and back, away from your ears
Ensure the knee pad is secure to prevent being lifted off the seat
Warm up with lighter weight before increasing resistance
beginnerTips: Think about pulling with your elbows, not your hands
Imagine trying to put your elbows in your back pockets
Exhale as you pull down, inhale as you release
Start with a weight that allows you to complete 10-12 reps with good form
Focus on feeling the work in your back muscles, not your arms

name: Chest Press Machine
setupSteps: Adjust the seat height so the handles are at mid-chest level
Sit with your back flat against the pad, feet firmly on the ground
Grip the handles with palms facing down or slightly inward
Your elbows should be bent at about 90 degrees in the starting position
Retract your shoulder blades (pull them back and down)
howToSteps: Press the handles forward until your arms are extended but not locked
Keep your wrists straight and elbows slightly below shoulder level
Pause briefly at full extension
Slowly return the handles to the starting position with control
Feel the stretch in your chest before starting the next rep
commonMistakes: Arching the lower back excessively off the pad
Pressing with elbows flared too high above shoulder level
Locking out elbows completely at full extension
Moving too fast without controlling the weight
Letting shoulders roll forward instead of staying retracted
safetyTips: Keep your shoulder blades pinned to the pad throughout
Don't let the weight stack crash between reps
Stop if you feel sharp pain in your shoulders or chest
Avoid using momentum to press the weight
Make sure the seat height is correct before adding heavy weight
beginnerTips: Exhale as you press forward, inhale as you return
Keep your core tight to stabilize your torso
Focus on squeezing your chest muscles at the top of the press
Start with 3 sets of 10-12 reps
The movement should feel smooth, not jerky or forced

name: Seated Cable Row
setupSteps: Sit on the machine and place your feet on the footrests
Slightly bend your knees to avoid locking them out
Reach forward and grab the handles with both hands
Sit upright with your chest up and shoulders back
There should be tension on the cable in this starting position
howToSteps: Pull the handles toward your torso while keeping your back straight
Drive your elbows back and squeeze your shoulder blades together
Pull the handles to your lower ribcage or upper abdomen
Pause and squeeze at the end of the pull
Slowly extend your arms back to the starting position with control
commonMistakes: Rounding the back or slouching forward
Using momentum by rocking back and forth
Pulling too high toward the chest or too low toward the waist
Not fully squeezing shoulder blades together at the end
Shrugging shoulders instead of keeping them down
safetyTips: Keep your torso upright and stable throughout the movement
Don't lean too far forward or backward
Maintain a neutral spine to protect your lower back
If your lower back feels strained, reduce the weight
Ensure footrests are secure before pulling heavy weight
beginnerTips: Think about pulling your elbows back rather than pulling with your hands
Keep your chest proud and shoulders down
Exhale as you pull toward you, inhale as you release
Start with moderate weight for 3 sets of 10-12 reps
Imagine squeezing a pencil between your shoulder blades

name: Shoulder Press Machine
setupSteps: Adjust the seat so the handles are at shoulder height when seated
Sit with your back firmly against the pad
Plant your feet flat on the floor for stability
Grip the handles with palms facing forward or neutral (depending on machine)
Ensure your elbows are bent at about 90 degrees in the starting position
howToSteps: Press the handles upward in a controlled motion
Extend your arms overhead but don't lock out your elbows completely
Keep your core engaged and back against the pad
Slowly lower the handles back to shoulder level
Maintain control as the weight returns to the starting position
commonMistakes: Arching the lower back excessively during the press
Using momentum or bouncing at the bottom
Locking elbows aggressively at the top
Letting the head jut forward instead of staying neutral
Pressing unevenly with one arm doing more work
safetyTips: Keep your back pressed against the pad to avoid strain
Don't use weight that's too heavy to control
Stop if you feel sharp pain in your shoulders or neck
Warm up your shoulders with lighter weight or arm circles first
Avoid shrugging your shoulders toward your ears
beginnerTips: Exhale as you press up, inhale as you lower down
Focus on pressing evenly with both arms
Keep your wrists straight throughout the movement
Start with 3 sets of 8-10 reps with moderate weight
This exercise requires good shoulder mobilityâ€”stretch before starting

name: Treadmill
setupSteps: Stand on the side rails of the treadmill
Attach the safety clip to your clothing
Select your workout or use the quick start option
Start the treadmill at a slow speed (1-2 mph)
Step onto the moving belt and begin walking
howToSteps: Maintain an upright posture with your head up and shoulders back
Swing your arms naturally
Increase the speed and/or incline to your desired intensity
To stop, press the stop button or gradually decrease the speed
Wait for the belt to come to a complete stop before stepping off
commonMistakes: Holding onto the handrails
Looking down at your feet
Taking strides that are too long
Stopping abruptly without using the stop button
Jumping off the treadmill while it's still moving
safetyTips: Always use the safety clip
Don't look at your feet
Don't hold on to the handrails
Don't stop abruptly
Don't jump off the treadmill
beginnerTips: Start with a walking pace to get comfortable
Gradually increase the speed and incline over time
Listen to your body and don't push yourself too hard
Stay hydrated by drinking water before, during, and after your workout
Cool down with a slow walk at the end of your workout

name: Rowing Machine
setupSteps: Sit on the seat and secure your feet in the footrests.
Adjust the straps to fit snugly across the balls of your feet.
Grab the handle with an overhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart.
Slide forward until your shins are vertical and your arms are straight.
howToSteps: Begin the 'drive' by pushing powerfully with your legs.
Once your legs are nearly straight, lean back slightly and pull the handle towards your lower chest.
Finish the stroke by pulling your elbows back and squeezing your shoulder blades.
For the 'recovery', extend your arms, then lean your torso forward, and finally bend your knees to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Pulling with the arms first instead of driving with the legs.
Rounding the back or hunching the shoulders.
Letting the knees come up too early in the recovery.
Shooting the hips back too quickly.
safetyTips: Keep your back straight and core engaged throughout the movement.
Don't hyper-extend your knees at the end of the drive.
Control the movement on the recovery; don't just let the machine pull you.
Start with a lower damper setting to focus on form.
beginnerTips: Focus on a smooth, continuous motion.
The rhythm should be 'legs, body, arms' on the drive and 'arms, body, legs' on the recovery.
Keep a consistent pace and focus on your breathing.
Aim for a stroke rate of 20-25 strokes per minute to start.

name: Elliptical Machine
setupSteps: Step onto the machine, one foot on each pedal.
Grasp the handlebars for stability.
Begin moving your feet in a striding motion to start the machine.
Adjust the resistance and incline to your desired level.
howToSteps: Maintain an upright posture with your chest up and shoulders back.
Push and pull the handlebars to engage your upper body.
Keep a smooth, fluid motion in your legs.
To go in reverse, simply pedal backward.
commonMistakes: Leaning on the handlebars, which reduces the work your legs do.
Slouching or rounding your back.
Not using the handlebars, which neglects the upper body workout.
Staying at the same resistance and incline level for every workout.
safetyTips: Keep your feet flat on the pedals.
Don't lock your knees.
Maintain a light grip on the handlebars.
Stop if you feel dizzy or lightheaded.
beginnerTips: Start with a lower resistance and incline until you get used to the motion.
Focus on maintaining good posture.
Try pedaling backward to work different muscles.
Aim for 20-30 minutes of continuous exercise.

name: Exercise Bike
setupSteps: Adjust the seat height so that your knee is slightly bent at the bottom of the pedal stroke.
Adjust the handlebars to a comfortable height.
If using toe cages, slip your feet in and tighten the straps.
Select a workout program or set the resistance manually.
howToSteps: Begin pedaling at a comfortable pace.
Maintain a consistent speed and resistance.
Keep your back straight and your core engaged.
To increase the intensity, increase the resistance or your pedaling speed.
commonMistakes: Setting the seat too high or too low.
Hunching over the handlebars.
Pedaling with only your toes.
Not using enough resistance.
safetyTips: Make sure the bike is on a level surface.
Keep your shoelaces tucked in.
Don't pedal too fast without any resistance.
Stop if you feel any pain in your knees or hips.
beginnerTips: Start with a 5-10 minute warm-up at a low resistance.
Gradually increase the duration and intensity of your workouts.
Cool down with 5 minutes of easy pedaling at the end of your workout.
Stay hydrated by drinking water before, during, and after your workout.

name: Stair Climber
setupSteps: Step onto the machine and select your workout program.
Start at a slow speed to get used to the motion.
Place your hands lightly on the handrails for balance.
howToSteps: Maintain an upright posture, with your back straight and core engaged.
Step up and down in a continuous motion.
Push through your heels to engage your glutes.
To increase the intensity, increase the speed or the duration of your workout.
commonMistakes: Leaning heavily on the handrails.
Slouching or rounding your back.
Taking small, quick steps instead of full steps.
Looking down at your feet.
safetyTips: Use the handrails for balance, not to support your body weight.
Keep your core engaged to protect your lower back.
Stop if you feel dizzy or lightheaded.
Be careful when getting on and off the machine.
beginnerTips: Start with shorter workouts and gradually increase the duration.
Focus on maintaining good form.
Don't be afraid to start at a slower speed.
Listen to your body and rest when you need to.

name: Smith Machine Squat
setupSteps: Set the barbell on the Smith machine to a height that is slightly below your shoulders.
Position yourself under the bar with the bar resting on your upper back.
Grasp the bar with both hands, wider than shoulder-width apart.
Unrack the bar by lifting it up and rotating it to release the safety hooks.
howToSteps: Place your feet shoulder-width apart, either directly under the bar or slightly in front.
Keeping your back straight and chest up, lower your hips as if you are sitting in a chair.
Descend until your thighs are parallel to the floor, or as low as you can comfortably go.
Push through your heels to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Letting your knees cave inward.
Rounding your back.
Not going low enough.
Placing the bar on your neck instead of your upper back.
safetyTips: Set the safety stoppers to a height that will catch the bar if you fail a rep.
Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Control the weight on the way down; don't let it drop.
Start with a lighter weight to get used to the movement.
beginnerTips: Experiment with your foot placement to find what is most comfortable for you.
Focus on maintaining a controlled, smooth movement.
Don't be afraid to use the safety features of the machine.
Ask a trainer or experienced gym-goer to check your form.

name: Cable Crossover
setupSteps: Set the pulleys on a cable machine to the desired height (high, middle, or low).
Select a light to moderate weight on each stack.
Grasp a handle in each hand.
Step forward to create tension on the cables, with one foot slightly in front of the other.
howToSteps: With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the handles forward and together in a wide arc.
Squeeze your chest muscles at the peak of the contraction.
Slowly return your arms to the starting position, controlling the weight.
Keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, which can lead to poor form.
Bending your elbows too much, turning the exercise into a press.
Rounding your back or shoulders.
Not controlling the weight on the way back.
safetyTips: Start with a light weight to master the form.
Keep a slight bend in your elbows to avoid straining them.
Don't let the weight stacks touch between reps.
Stop if you feel any pain in your shoulders or chest.
beginnerTips: Focus on the mind-muscle connection, really feeling your chest muscles work.
Experiment with different pulley heights to target different parts of your chest.
Keep the movement slow and controlled.
Exhale as you pull the handles together and inhale as you return to the start.

name: Preacher Curl Machine
setupSteps: Adjust the seat height so that your armpits are just over the top of the arm pad.
Rest your upper arms on the pad, with your palms facing up.
Grasp the handles with an underhand grip.
howToSteps: Slowly curl the weight up towards your shoulders.
Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement.
Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position.
Do not fully extend your arms at the bottom to keep tension on the biceps.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight and using momentum to lift the weight.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.
Lifting the elbows off the pad.
Going too fast and not controlling the weight.
safetyTips: Do not hyperextend your elbows at the bottom of the movement.
Keep your wrists straight throughout the exercise.
Start with a lighter weight to ensure proper form.
If you feel pain in your elbows, stop the exercise.
beginnerTips: Focus on a slow and controlled movement.
Really squeeze your biceps at the top of the curl.
Don't be afraid to use a lighter weight to get the form right.
Exhale as you curl the weight up and inhale as you lower it.

name: Tricep Extension Machine
setupSteps: Adjust the seat height so that your elbows are in line with the machine's pivot point.
Place your upper arms flat on the pad.
Grasp the handles with an overhand grip.
howToSteps: Extend your arms downward until they are fully extended.
Squeeze your triceps at the bottom of the movement.
Slowly return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight and using momentum.
Lifting your elbows off the pad.
Not fully extending your arms.
Moving too quickly and not controlling the weight.
safetyTips: Do not lock your elbows at the bottom of the movement.
Keep your wrists straight.
Start with a lighter weight to ensure proper form.
If you feel pain in your elbows, stop the exercise.
beginnerTips: Focus on a slow and controlled movement.
Squeeze your triceps at the bottom of the extension.
Keep your upper arms stationary on the pad.
Exhale as you extend your arms and inhale as you return to the start.

name: Leg Extension Machine
setupSteps: Adjust the back pad so that your knees are in line with the machine's pivot point.
Adjust the ankle pad so that it rests comfortably on your lower shins.
Select a light to moderate weight.
howToSteps: Extend your legs until they are straight, but do not lock your knees.
Squeeze your quadriceps at the top of the movement.
Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight and momentum.
Swinging the weight up and down.
Locking the knees at the top of the movement.
Not controlling the weight on the way down.
safetyTips: Do not lock your knees.
Keep the movement slow and controlled.
If you have knee problems, consult with a doctor or physical therapist before using this machine.
Stop if you feel any pain in your knees.
beginnerTips: Start with a light weight to focus on form.
Focus on squeezing your quadriceps at the top of the movement.
Control the weight throughout the entire range of motion.
Exhale as you extend your legs and inhale as you lower them.
